key_facts: LinkedIn Series B pitch presented three business ideas with no current revenue.
The three business ideas were not the source of LinkedIn's majority revenue.
Initial belief was that individual subscription would drive LinkedIn's success.
Corporate product interest emerged two weeks after launching the subscription model.
A paper mock-up of the corporate product was created before actual development began.
A salesperson was hired to test market interest in the corporate product.
Twenty out of thirty contacted companies expressed interest in purchasing the corporate product.
Company pivoted to prioritize the corporate product as the main revenue driver.
The corporate product became the majority revenue source for LinkedIn.
The pivot occurred earlier than expected, shifting focus from individual subscriptions.
key_opinions: Presenting three options during the pitch reflects uncertainty about the winning model.
The shift to corporate product was a strategic necessity due to early market demand.
The initial assumption about individual subscriptions was incorrect.
The corporate product opportunity was unexpected but highly promising.
The pivot demonstrated agility in responding to real customer interest.
key_datapoints: Two weeks after subscription launch, companies began inquiring about corporate product.
Twenty-plus companies showed interest in the corporate product out of thirty contacted.
Pivot occurred immediately after salesperson returned with positive feedback.
Corporate product became the majority revenue source for LinkedIn.
Expected timeline for corporate product was five years; actual implementation was much faster.
